bibl.title: Despatch from M. A. Aenmey to J. C. Bancroft Davis
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.persName: Davis, J. C. Bancroft (John Chandler Bancroft), 1822-1907

div1.p: Mr M. A. Aenmey to the Assistant Secretary of State
Account of miscellaneous expences from the Consular Agency at Grand Bassa for Sept 1882

Consulate General of the U.S.
Monrovia April 26, 1882

I have the honor to return to the Department the enclosed account of Miscellaneous Expences for the U.S. Consular Agency at Grand Bassa, Sept 17 1881. The Draft, I handed to Capt Tubey for endorsement, afther being signed by the Consular Agent
I regret deeply the delay, occured in returning this account, to the Department, which was caused by the absence of mail steamers at this port, for the last five weeks.

I must respectfully enclose also a dispatch from Mr Worrell by his special request, and can at the same time assure the Department that Mr Worrell was suppleid, by Minister Smyth, with the Consular Regulations of 1881.

I have the honor to be Sir
Your obedt servt
M. A Aenmey
Actg Consul General
div1.fw:
Honble J. C. Bancroft Davis
Assistant Secretary of State
Washington D.C.
div1.p:
1. Miscellaneous expences. (Consular Agency)
2. Dispatch from Mr Worrell to Department

The Hon: Second
Ass: Secretary of State
Washington D.C.

On the 11th instant I received, through the Legation at Monrovia, a dispatch addressed to Hon: J. H. Smyth, Ex Minister Resident, in which you complain of irregularities &c &c. In apologizing for said irregularities I beg most respectfully to say that the same occurred in consequence of the literal construction I placed on paragraph 526 of the Consular Regulations for 1881. Page 180

In
In the present dispatch I beg to inclose Missellaneous account No 1 for freight &c &c on Consular Arms for this Agency. I have further to advise that I have drawn draft for Thirty dollars–dated Sept 17 1881 to cover said amount for fright &c &c which I hope will be found in order.

Since my incumbency, and the change in this Consulate (from Commercial Agent to Consular Agent) all my quarterly returns have been transmitted to the Department through the Legation at Monrovia, and in order to avoid a recurrence of other irregularities I beg most respectfully to be advised if I shall continue said course or make my Returns, in future, to
to the Department at Washington direct.

I am Sir,
Your obt Svt
John W Worrell
U.S. Consular Agent
